718262f-a.title: Manhattan: Central Park - Terrace Fountain and the Lake - The Mall.
718262f-a.text:
Central Park, the Mall: Bethesda Fountain, on the shore of the Lake (eastern bay), above the Esplanade at the nothern end of the Mall. The design is by Miss Emma Stebbins, a New York sculptor: and represents the angel blessing the waters of the pool of Bethesda. In her left hand the angel holds a branch of lilies, emblem of purity. The four figures supporting the basin symbolize Temperance, Purity, Health, and Peace.
May 1892.
Ewing Galloway.
718262f-a.folder: Central Park & Terrace Fountain and the Lake & The Mall., Manhattan, NY

730665f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge.
730665f-a.text:
The Brooklyn Bridge under construction, with the "Catwalk" and Manhattan anchorage in the foreground. Also shown is a general view westward over the City Hall and Printing House Square area, to the Hudson River, with its Jersey shore line just beyond. Note how the U.S. Post Office and the Tribune Buildings predominated at this date.
About 1878-1879.
Ewing Galloway.

East 42nd Street, north side, east from Fifth Ave., showing construction work in progress on Grand Central Station, Vanderbilt Ave., to Depew Flace (no longer in existence. Grand Central station was opened in 1913 and is the terminal for the new York Central Railroad, and the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad
Prior to 1913.

Ewing Galloway.

718179f-b.title: Manhattan: Central Park - Aerial view from Radio City.
718179f-b.text:
(1)
Central Park: Aerial View from Radio City (Sixth Avenue and 51st Street), showing the Park and the Fifth Avenue side. In the center foreground may be seen the Pond, north of it tho l(all, then the Lake, of which the eastern bay is at thc northern end of the Mall and the main body on the west side of the Park, about 70th to 80th Streets. The bare spot further north is the site of the old reservoir; above it may be seen the nor reservoir, still in use. The buildings of the Metropolitan Museum of Art may be seen on the Fifth Avenue side at 81st
Street.
August 9, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, another view. In the southwestern quarter of the Park may bo seen a ball ground, and north of it the Meadow or Green. The 72nd Street cross drive separates the Green and
the Lake.
August 9, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
718179f-b.folder: Central Park & Aerial view from Radio City., Manhattan, NY

730663f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge.
730663f-a.text:
A general view westward from the Brooklyn Bridge (under construction), over the Cherry Hill section, Printing House Square, City Hall Commons and westward to the Hudson (North) River. Shown in the foreground, is the Manhattan abutment of the bridge, with the Roosevelt Street Ferry to Broadway, Brooklyn adjoining. Points of interest shown are, U.S. Post Office,
Tribune Building, Harper's and the Newsboy's Home.
About 1870-1875.
Brown Brothers.
Published in the American on December 1906, and the New York Times
of October 20, 1912.

706346f-a.title: Brooklyn: Prospect Park Plaza.
706346f-a.text:
Prospect Park,Plaza: A general view east from the Knights of Columbus Building located at the N.W. corner of President Street and Prospect Park West, showing in the foreground the Memorial Arch.  In the center of the view, east from Flatbush Ave., (trolley car thereon) is Eastern Parkway.  The buildings on the south side of the Parkway are the Mt. Prospect Reservoir, and the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences; on the north side in their order are the Union Temple of Brooklyn, the Copley Plaza Apartments (under construction), the Abraham Lincoln, etc.

June 1926.

Brown Brothers.

716520f-c.title: Manhattan: Battery Park - Aquarium.
716520f-c.text:
Battery Park;  A set of three views westward across the southwestern corner of same, showing the Aquarium at the foot of the North (Hudson) River.  Across the latter appears the New Jersey shoreline.  In Nos. 2 and 3, we see the giant "Normandie" putting to sea.
september 16, 1936

F. L. Sperr.

718284f.title: Manhattan: Central Park.
718284f.text:
TEN THOUSAND NEW YORK SCHOOLBOYS DRILLING IN CENTRAL PARK.
This is a great army (aray?) of schoolboys from all boroughs of the big city, attired in white shirtwaists & dark knickerbockers, gave an exhibition drill in the physical exercises in the city's largest park last month before a distinguished company of invited guests, relatives & friends.  The purpose of this impressive demonstration, which was held under the auspices of the Public Schools Athletic League, was to show the results of physical and hygienic training in the schools.  Colonel Roosevelt, who was one of the spectators, spoke of the work of the League as a great force for good not only in the city but in the nation.

Dated:  June 10, 1913.  American Press Ass'n
Neg # 2333

730622f-a.title: Staten Island - Poppy Joe Island Beach - [Stroud place.]
730622f-a.text:
Poppy Joe Island Beach (Staten Islard): A group of local muskrat Dunters and hunting dogs in front of their work-and-storage barn. From left to right they are: Louis Stroud, George W. Stroud, John ('Jaff') Dayis, and James A. Stroud. Poppy Joe Island is on the Lower Vew York Bay, near New Creek, between Ocean Breeze and Midland Beach.
About 1911
Photo by J.E. Davis
Copied by P. L. Sperr

718268f-b.title: Manhattan: Central Park - The Mall.
718268f-b.text:
(1)
Central Park: The Mall, crowd with roller skaters. During this and the following year, this sport, always more or less popular, suddenly became a craze; young, middle aged, and old, children and adults all took to roller skates. The Mall and the Central Park walks, together with the east sidewalk of Central Park West, were favorite locations, but by no means the only ones.
May 15, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, annothcr view.
May 15, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
The same another view.
The seated statue represents Fitz-Creene Halleck, by Wilson
MacDonald (erected in 1877).
May 15, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
718268f-b.folder: Central Park & The Mall., Manhattan, NY

701498f-b.text:
Morris Park Race Track (Bronx); Viewing north across the fashionable track from near the grand stand. The track wss bounded on the east by Williamshridge Road; on the west by Parnes Avenue; on the north by Pelham Parkway; and on the south by Sacket Avenue. In June, 1913 "the most remarkable real estate sale in the history of the city", as the New York Times commented editorially, took place when the track property was offered for auction by Joseph P. Day and Clarence Davies. For additional data see "The New York Times," April 27, June 15,
and June 22, 1913.
MAY BE REPRODUCED  About 1910
Views 1,2:
1.
